Informatica MDM Services Integration Framework (SIF) SDK

 

See: Description

Client API 
Package Description
com.siperian.mrm  
com.siperian.sif.client
API to execute SIF requests on a remote Siperian Hub Server using a single class, SiperianClient, that abstracts a choice of protocols: EJB, SOAP, and HTTP.
Master Reference Manager (MRM) messages 
Package Description
com.siperian.sif.message
Provides data objects and abstract classes for the Siperian Hub APIs.
com.siperian.sif.message.metadata
Provides data objects for Siperian Hub meta-data - data describing objects defined in the Siperian Hub.
com.siperian.sif.message.mrm
MRM message API.
Hierarchy Manager (HM) messages 
Package Description
com.siperian.sif.message.hm
Provides request and response objects for Siperian Hub Hierarchy Manager APIs.
Activity Manager (AM) messages 
Package Description
com.siperian.sif.message.am
Provides request and response objects for Siperian Hub Activity Manager APIs.
MRM Custom Cleanse Function API 
Package Description
com.siperian.mrm.cleanse.api  
com.siperian.mrm.cleanse.api.tools  
Other Packages 
Package Description
com.siperian.mrm.message  
com.siperian.mrm.workflow  
com.siperian.mrm.workflow.activevos  
com.siperian.mrm.workflow.activevos2  
com.siperian.sif.message.event  
com.siperian.sif.message.event.am  

SIF is the API to a remote Siperian Hub to retrieve or update data. The API provides a coarse-grain request/response message model and a client class for transferring messages. A choice of protocols are supported by the same Java API: EJB, SOAP, and HTTP. These docs should also be used for the non-Java WSDL/XSD Soap API - the XML uses the same element names as Java classes and methods.

SiperianClient and API Requests

There are multiple ways to programmatically access the Siperian Hub Server. All offer the functionality of sending API requests to a remote Siperian Hub Server and receiving responses. The options are:

  • Java – Using the SiperianClient library.
  • SOAP Web services – Full WSDL for all operations is available at http://localhost:7001/cmx/request/wsdl
    • .
  • HTTP – Requests expressed in XML can be sent via POST to the server at http://localhost:7001/cmx/request/process. The XML schema for the requests and responses is available at: http://localhost:7001/cmx/request/xsd/siperian-core.xsd and http://localhost:7001/cmx/request/xsd/siperian-types.xsd

Details on usage of the Web services and HTTP protocol can be found in the Siperian Hub Services Integration Guide (Siperian_Hub_SIF_Guide.pdf).

Java API: SiperianClient

The SiperianClient library and javadocs are installed with the Siperian Hub Resource Kit in the resourcekit\sifsdk folder. The SIF SDK can be used for creating custom web services to be deployed along with the Siperan Hub server. These custom web services would typically be built using the SiperianClient library. See sample code for building web services using the SIF SDK in the resourcekit/samples folders.

The SiperianCllient library is provided for easy and efficient Java applications. There are two parts to the API:

  • The MRM, HM, and AM, packages provides request and response objects for each of the available operations.
  • The com.siperian.sif.client package manages the details of communication with the Siperian Hub Server. SiperianClient can be configured for the desired protocol to communicate with the Siperian Hub Server: EJB, SOAP, or XML over HTTP.

The API may be used to develop various types of applications, such as:

  • Web Services that provide a higher level, application/domain specific API.
  • BPM and Workflow integration using the Java API or SOAP directly.
  • A Java Swing UI can use it to query, view, and edit data in the Siperian Hub.
  • Server components in a J2EE application server can use it to get and update data in the Siperian Hub. An EJB can seamlessly integrate with the transactions of the Siperian Hub.
  • A JSP or Servlet application can use it to present a portal view including Siperian Hub data.
  • Command-line application to run Batch Jobs and Groups, to be run manually, scheduled for periodic execution, or included as part of another script or application.
